issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description: Users in eucalyptus account should be able to manage (and view) resources in other accounts. Using latest euca2ools, as a admin in eucalyptus account I could not delete an LB created by a non-eucalyptus account.
fields.summary: eucalyptus account can't delete an LB of another account

comments.body: [~rusvika] One problem is that there could be multiple LBs belong to different accounts with the same name. I'll go ahead and delete the LB if there's only one match, but for multiple matches I'll throw exception.
[~spark], there should be a way to identify each LB uniquely, for example, by the account id and LB name. [~gholms] can help you with implementing an extra CLI param if needed.
account id + lb name pair is the unique identifier. [~gholms] let me know if you're ok with the idea and have the tool ready.
[~rusvika] actually, another way to implement this is to use DNS name of the LB for delete key. [~gholms] if you're ok with that, plz reassign the ticket to me.

That'd be one way to do it, but the consensus seems to be that express consent is preferable to server-side magic where possible as far as new stuff goes.  See the Euare service, for instance.  A separate parameter like Euare's {{DelegateAccount}} would be preferable in the short term.  I can add the option to the command line tool for that.

[~decker], do you have any additional thoughts on this?

yes please reassign to me whenever the tool's ready.


On Fri, Apr 26, 2013 at 3:42 PM, Garrett Holmstrom (JIRA) <
I need to know what spec I'm writing to first.  [~decker], any preferences on what this should look like, or shall I just pick something?
[~gholms] did our conversation the other day address this issue?  I'm reassigning this one to you and can follow up as needed.

[~decker]'s recommendation was to interpret an admin's request with a load balancer name that happens to match a load balancer's ARN as one that refers specifically to that load balancer.  In other words, pretty much what [~spark] suggested, just with an ARN instead of a DNS name.

As far as I can tell, load balancers don't have user-visible ARNs -- I'd rather go with DNS names if we can because those are AWS compatible and easy to obtain.  But does that work when you don't have DNS enabled?

Either way, this isn't going to involve client-side changes.  If we go with ARNs, we will also need to tell people how to construct them.

Chris?

So, there is a unique name defined for all resource types:  the ARN.  We can consider having additional canonical names (why?), but we should uniformly have ARN support.

Even if AWS doesn't expose ARNs for a resource type, there is a canonical form which can be applied as defined in:

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/aws-arns-and-namespaces.html#arns-syntax
I'm opting for DNS name. it's the only unique identifier that's always returned with describe-loadbalancers verbose.

If ARN is to be used for this purpose, we should uniformly change it across service operations. Still it could be confusing as ELB has no associated ARN per AWS docs. We need something that will go in 3.3 right now.

[~spark]  Understood.  That means we should support both ARNs and DNS.

That the DNS name is a canonical identifier returned by DescribeLoadBalancers is a good reason to support it.  

ARNs are already usable as canonical identifiers for many resources.  They are the naming scheme defined by AWS for resources and we must support them for compat -- regardless of whether they show up in AWS services today or not it is the specified naming scheme.  

Here I am only talking about support in ELB at the moment and dont think it is predicated on adding support to any other resource types.
Ok I'll go ahead and support both naming convention for admin.

Found that our arn parser (Ern.java) is not really ready to support this (i.e., account is ignored in the regex match). Since we run out of time, we won't support ARN-based naming in the delete operation.

Fix Verified.

As admin user in eucalyptus account I am able to delete a LB of another account.

Installed Packages
Name        : eucalyptus
Arch        : x86_64
Version     : 3.3.0
Release     : 0.0.965.20130517gitc1fcc79a.el6
